I just played this game for 21 hours straight on my first time playing and I still haven't cracked the surface of the complexity of this game. I started by not using the tutorial to get a feel for things but now that I have rebirthed a few times with increasing empires, I'm ready to see how I'm supposed to play the game.

One of the best idle games I've ever played.
If you are a fan of the civilization game series this is a game for you. It's just like a very simple and still complexe civ game.

I liked the author's previous work with industry idle. I was hoping this would have more military, building off of industry idles tower defense approach. [h1]The Little Number Into Big Number Game That Is Consuming Me[/h1]

[hr]
I opened CivIdle expecting a flimsy browser-looking time killer and instead discovered a grand strategy game wearing a grey Excel cosplay. It is free, it is allegedly “idle,” and it has quietly become the most powerful productivity-destroying engine in my fucking life. I installed it to relax; now I am optimizing Stone Age pottery yields at 3 a.m. while the game’s slogan, “empire must grow and numbers must go up,” echoes in my skull like a cult mantra.

I originally expected a bland clicker because the UI looks like an old Windows operating system that somehow wandered onto Steam by accident. Then the depth hit me. Underneath the unassuming boxes and tiny icons is a tech tree with 100+ technologies that drags you from wood and stone to virtual reality and artificial intelligence, unlocking new systems every time you think you have finally understood what is happening. The late stages of the game are still a distant dream to me. One moment I am discovering “Masonry,” the next I am making urban planning decisions and wondering whether my civilization will fail as I make upgrade effectively bringing operations to a grinding halt. This is [b]not a reskinned cookie clicker[/b]; [u]it is Civilization’s overachieving cousin that decided sleep is an optional and a mechanic that simulates your AFK for when sleep isn't possible to resist anymore.[/u]

The real core loop, though, is watching numbers climb while you do absolutely nothing, and CivIdle has perfected that dark art. Like all incremental games, it starts with manual clicks, then steadily automates itself until you are just tuning multipliers like a master of all domains yet somehow staring at production processes like a very confused neanderthal piecing together the fabric of existence. The wild part is that it feels good both ways: it is just as satisfying to step away for a few hours and come back to a resource tsunami as it is to sit there, totally AFK in your brain, watching the integers tick up while a show plays on your second monitor. The “idle” in CivIdle is less a feature and more a lifestyle recommendation. Continuously since I downloaded it yesterday my brain has been racing to optimize supply chains of little 2D production  building. It is absurd how quickly this game has taken hold.

The world itself is simple but elegant. Every run drops you on a procedurally generated map full of resources and natural wonders to exploit, and as you move through eras you transform your slice of the hex tiled grid to serve your industrial nonsense. Wonders are not just stat sticks; they are weird little personality tests. CivIdle lets you express yourself both as a responsible ruler and as an absolute menace to urban planning.

CivIdle hands you a global economy and says, “Here, try not to crash this.” You can trade via Markets that reroll resource exchange pairs every hour, or go fully feral capitalist with the Caravansary, where you claim a tile on the world map and start trading directly with other players. Suddenly my chill idle game had me min-maxing iron-for-coal swaps, undercutting strangers, and role-playing as a hyperactive Silk Road merchant who refuses to log off until the stone market “stabilizes.” Add in the rebirth system, with ranks like Quaestor that reset your run for permanent bonuses, and you get this wonderful, deranged loop of blowing up your own civilization on purpose because the numbers might go up even faster next time.

Finally, the business model feels almost suspiciously kind. The base game is free-to-play across PC and mobile, with a Supporter Pack that exists basically so people like me can throw money at Fish Pond Studio out of sheer gratitude and mild guilt I bought without a second thought. There is even a separate Cross Platform Cloud Save DLC that is [u]coming soon[/u] if you want to sync your empire between Steam and mobile, which is how you know the devs have fully accepted that we will be checking our wheat output from the grocery store. I picked up the Supporter Pack DLC purely to support the creator, because any game that lets me AFK my way from Stone Age to a Dyson Sphere probably deserves more money than the coffee I forgot to drink while playing it.

[hr]

[b]TL;DR:[/b] CivIdle looks simple, but it is absurdly deep, aggressively addictive, and somehow both relaxing and all-consuming at the same time. If "telling yourself you have other things to do, yet you sit down anyway, eight hours pass when you suddenly realize it's 3:00am, setup a large scale upgrade path until 3:30am, leave game, sleep, come back embarrassingly too short a time later at 6:40am, and stare in enthralled glee at bigger numbers" sounds remotely appealing, this thing will sink its hooks into you fast. I have not “finished” CivIdle, and honestly I am not sure such a state exists; I am just happily obsessed, rebirthing my civilization, tweaking trade routes, and convincing myself that the next tech unlock will finally let me log off like a normal human being. It will not. The empire must grow, and the numbers must go up.

Almost 400 hours in. Having a blast. Restarted my civ a few dozen times so far exploring the different nation's passives. Collecting great people to boost your civ becomes likes a magic card addiction.
The community is a pleasant breath of fresh air in the modern chat-o-sphere. Lot's of theory crafting going in in chat.
You can check your city briefly and play into a more idle style of gaming, or dig in for hours with active grinding if you enjoy micromanaging, city planning and resource management.

Got it for free. Played a few days with the normal "new free game" skepticism while I adjusted to the learning curve.
My defenses were disarmed a few days in when I realized I was daydreaming build orders and city layouts while at work. Bought the DLC to support the 1-man dev (active, still providing updates). The DLC is so cheap and the game is so good that it feels like i'd be stealing fun if I continued free to play.

The U.I. is retro and I love everything about it. The worker/transportation/happiness system is fun to manage and gives you a general guide of how hard you are pushing yourself. Be patient when you start out and use chat if you are stumped.
P.s. you will be rewarded if you actually expand the tooltips and read the dropdown menus. Tons of gameplay options and advanced toggles to boost quality of life.
Have fun and hit me up in game.

I've been playing this game for nearly two months now, and I've generally enjoyed it. The UI is generally quite easy to understand and functional, the game is stable and designed to run on a potato, and there's enough gameplay progression here to keep you tabbing back for a while.

The DLC gives instant access to rank 2 (important for trading) and the ability to play as all the civs, but there's no need to own it to get a full game experience, so there's as much "try it before you buy" as you could ask.

The descriptions for some of the stats aren't great (at least in English), which can lead to some suboptimal play for new people, but chat will generally have someone willing to explain the details, and frequently to trade you commodities to grow your empire. 

This isn't my favorite game, but it's given me a very high return on purchase price, so I'm generally satisfied

There is even a separate Cross Platform Cloud Save DLC that is [u]coming soon[/u] if you want to sync your empire between Steam and mobile, which is how you know the devs have fully accepted that we will be checking our wheat output from the grocery store. I picked up the Supporter Pack DLC purely to support the creator, because any game that lets me AFK my way from Stone Age to a Dyson Sphere probably deserves more money than the coffee I forgot to drink while playing it.

[hr]

[b]TL;DR:[/b] CivIdle looks simple, but it is absurdly deep, aggressively addictive, and somehow both relaxing and all-consuming at the same time. If "telling yourself you have other things to do, yet you sit down anyway, eight hours pass when you suddenly realize it's 3:00am, setup a large scale upgrade path until 3:30am, leave game, sleep, come back embarrassingly too short a time later at 6:40am, and stare in enthralled glee at bigger numbers" sounds remotely appealing, this thing will sink its hooks into you fast. I have not “finished” CivIdle, and honestly I am not sure such a state exists; I am just happily obsessed, rebirthing my civilization, tweaking trade routes, and convincing myself that the next tech unlock will finally let me log off like a normal human being. It will not. The empire must grow, and the numbers must go up.

Almost 400 hours in. Having a blast. Restarted my civ a few dozen times so far exploring the different nation's passives. Collecting great people to boost your civ becomes likes a magic card addiction.
The community is a pleasant breath of fresh air in the modern chat-o-sphere. Lot's of theory crafting going in in chat.
You can check your city briefly and play into a more idle style of gaming, or dig in for hours with active grinding if you enjoy micromanaging, city planning and resource management.

Got it for free. Played a few days with the normal "new free game" skepticism while I adjusted to the learning curve.
My defenses were disarmed a few days in when I realized I was daydreaming build orders and city layouts while at work. Bought the DLC to support the 1-man dev (active, still providing updates). The DLC is so cheap and the game is so good that it feels like i'd be stealing fun if I continued free to play.

The U.I. is retro and I love everything about it. The worker/transportation/happiness system is fun to manage and gives you a general guide of how hard you are pushing yourself. Be patient when you start out and use chat if you are stumped.
P.s. you will be rewarded if you actually expand the tooltips and read the dropdown menus. Tons of gameplay options and advanced toggles to boost quality of life.
Have fun and hit me up in game.

CivIdle is one of the best idle games I have ever played. The supporter pack is definitely worth the price.

Nice game if you need to AFK and do stuff. Like a city/empire management game where you upgrade buildings and unlock stuff. Community chat is civil and respectable. Does require some strategic thinking.
great game I wish they would add some kind of combat,pretty good as is,,,

I just played this game for 21 hours straight on my first time playing and I still haven't cracked the surface of the complexity of this game. I started by not using the tutorial to get a feel for things but now that I have rebirthed a few times with increasing empires, I'm ready to see how I'm supposed to play the game.

It is "play at your own pace" and there is no means to "pay to win." Chat is active and helpful. The developer updates often, and occasionally engages in chat. There's really no way to do it "wrong," some people enjoy very fast progression and they can, others enjoy a slower paced progression and that works just as well. One of the best idle games I've ever played.
Idle game, so does things while you're gone, good for something to check in on for a few minutes at a time periodically throughout the day.
